title: Chapter 4 – Taxation of Group Risk (UK 2024/25) MCQs

questions.stem: For 2024/25 (rUK), which band applies to taxable income between £50,271 and £125,140?
options: Basic rate 20%
Higher rate 40%
Additional rate 45%
Starting rate 0%
questions.explanation: Standard rUK bands: basic 20% to £50,270; higher 40% £50,271–£125,140; additional 45% above £125,140. Scotland differs.

questions.stem: Which statement best describes the usual employee tax position for employer-paid GLA premiums under a discretionary trust?
options: Taxable benefit in kind reportable on P11D
Not a benefit in kind due to s307 ITEPA exemption for death benefits
Always taxed as savings income
Taxed only if benefit multiple exceeds 4× salary
questions.explanation: Death-in-service meeting s307 ITEPA is generally not a BIK; typically no P11D/Class 1A on premiums.

questions.stem: Which is MOST accurate for Group Income Protection (GIP) tax treatment at claim stage?
options: Payments are tax-free to the employee
Payments are typically taxed as earnings via PAYE; NICs may also apply depending on payroll setup
Payments are taxed as dividends
Payments are taxed only if the employee is a higher-rate taxpayer
questions.explanation: GIP replaces income and is usually taxed as earnings during claim.

questions.stem: Employer provides personal life cover for one director outside any registered/relevant life or group trust. What is the LIKELY treatment of the premium?
options: Not a benefit in kind (no reporting)
Taxable benefit in kind reportable on P11D; employer may owe Class 1A NIC
Taxed as savings income for the employer
Exempt under s307 automatically
questions.explanation: Non-qualifying personal cover paid by the employer is typically a BIK (P11D/Class 1A) for the employee.

options: Employee main rate 8%; employer 13.8%
Employee main rate 12%; employer 15%
Employee main rate 10%; employer 12%
Employee main rate 6%; employer 13.8%
questions.explanation: For 2024/25 rUK, employee Class 1 main rate 8% and employer Class 1 13.8% (rate references).

questions.stem: A company pays £20,000 for a registered GLA scheme under discretionary trust. Which is MOST likely?
options: Employees receive a P11D for their share of the premium
Employer can usually deduct the premium for corporation tax; no employee BIK under s307
Employees are charged at basic rate on the premium
Employer must pay Class 1A NIC on the premium
questions.explanation: Premiums are generally deductible; death-in-service premiums are not a BIK (s307), so no P11D/Class 1A.

questions.stem: Which statement about GLA benefits is MOST accurate?
options: Dependants’ lump-sum payments from a discretionary trust are usually outside the estate for IHT and not subject to income tax
Payments are taxed as employment income
Payments are taxed as savings interest
Payments are always subject to Class 1A NICs
questions.explanation: Typical death-in-service via trust is outside the estate and not income-taxable for the recipient.

questions.stem: GIP claim example (basic-rate taxpayer). Salary £40,000; policy target 60% after offsets. Monthly target ≈ £2,000. If no other income remains after offsets, which is MOST accurate?
options: Net ≈ £2,000 because GIP is tax-free
Net < £2,000 because PAYE tax (20%) and possibly 8% NICs reduce take-home
Net > £2,000 due to personal allowance
Net = £2,000 minus employer NICs
questions.explanation: GIP payments are typically taxed as earnings; NICs may apply depending on payroll setup, so net is below the headline percentage.

questions.stem: Which scenario MOST likely triggers a P11D/Class 1A NIC charge?
options: Registered GLA under discretionary trust
Relevant life policy meeting conditions
Employer-paid personal life policy for an individual (non-qualifying)
GIP premium for a standard employer policy
questions.explanation: Personal life cover paid by the employer that is not within qualifying structures is typically a BIK.

questions.stem: Which statement about corporation tax is MOST accurate for group risk premiums?
options: Generally deductible if incurred wholly and exclusively for the trade
Never deductible
Deductible only when employees are basic-rate taxpayers
Deductible only if there is a claim in that year
questions.explanation: Premiums are commonly deductible on the normal ‘wholly and exclusively’ test.
